video.title: Micro-Frontends Course - Beginner to Expert
video.description:
Don't know what a Micro-Frontend, but you've heard the buzz and you want to learn it. Let me take you from just starting out, to understanding asynchronous loading, error handling, shared state, cross platform micro-frontends, how to route multiple applications together, and even how to test Micro-Frontend code.

✏️ Jack's channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/JackHerrington

💻 Code: https://github.com/jherr/micro-fes-beginner-to-expert

⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:01:06) Micro-Frontend demo
⌨️ (0:08:13) Why Micro-Frontends?
⌨️ (0:11:50) Why Module Federation?
⌨️ (0:20:16) Asynchronous Loading
⌨️ (0:24:56) Error Handling
⌨️ (0:31:42) Server Setup
⌨️ (0:38:36) Sharing Functions
⌨️ (0:50:15) Nomenclature
⌨️ (0:51:35) Sever Cart Setup
⌨️ (0:59:28) Sharing State
⌨️ (1:02:42) Sharing the JWT
⌨️ (1:13:53) Sharing the Cart
⌨️ (1:26:48) State Sharing Alternatives
⌨️ (1:27:21) Finishing the Cart
⌨️ (1:29:36) Cross-Platform Micro-Frontends
⌨️ (1:39:02) Micro-Frontend Routing
⌨️ (1:48:24) Unit Testing
⌨️ (1:51:53) End-To-End Testing
⌨️ (1:54:55) What's Next?

#microFrontends #moduleFederation #react #solidjs

topLevelComment.author: szeredai akos
topLevelComment.text:
Why do you use the word share? In architecture that is called coupling.
So, in your header app.name is a little bit weird. You are essentially creating a layer of error handling across your project which deals with errors within the same project. That has a maintainability issue. Lets say, there is a 180 screen project with 10 different applications which makes use of the header. Ideally developed and maintained by 10 different teams.

And the contract changes.

Lets say 2 of the teams implemented proper error handling on remote components (I am exaggerating, there is less than 1 in 20 FE teams which have that amount of discipline). That leaves you with 8 teams which need to be coordinated to handle the contract change. Technical coordination of 8 teams ... do you have any idea how expensive that is?

So in essence, shared components in your context is NOT a positive feature.
Obviously, it can be rooted out with the O from SOLID. So, the proper way for doing it is {!!app && app.name}
Jus sayin :D

replies.author: szeredai akos
replies.text:
@Pradana GDE NPM just complicates things needlessly. The mechanism he described is solid but he uses it erroneously. You do need shared code, there is no doubt about that, but he has a shared component which is afferent to his application and efferent to contract which is digested on the application. That is essentially cross coupling. Pathological. You don't do that between apps, you don't do that between dev teams. Not even between 2 classes of the same app. Ever!

Setting up an error boundary, or the condition I mentioned ensures some degree of discreteness. If you have way too much of those conditions then you remove that component from the shared bucket and have it reimplemented on all applications. Parallel systems are way worse than duplicate code.

topLevelComment.author: Andrew Morgan
topLevelComment.text: In case anyone gets blocked when trying to add React Router: If you just install router as shown in the video (with npm/yarn) without specifying a version, you'll get React Router v6. This version has replaced the Switch component with a Routes (not Route) component but it behaves the same and also changed the "component" prop on Route to be "element". Route's "element" prop requires the component to be passed in as "<PDPContent />" not just PDPContent like in the video.
